A.F.C.|Swansea City]] | caps11= 80 | goals11= 2 | years12= 2017– | clubs12 = [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] | caps12= 65 | goals12= 3 | nationalyears1 = 2005 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 = 0 | nationalyears7 = 2012 | nationalteam7 = [[Great Britain Olympic football team|Great Britain]] | nationalcaps7 = 4 | nationalgoals7 = 0 | nationalyears8 = 2017– | nationalteam8 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps8 = 1 | nationalgoals8 = 0 | club-update = 21:25, 27 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 00:23, 10 December 2018 (UTC) }} '''Jack Frank Porteous Cork''' (born 25 June 1989) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for {{English football updater|Burnley}} club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. He played for the [[Great Britain Olympic football team|Great Britain Olympic team]] at the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Summer Olympics]].
Cork started off his career with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] but between 2006 and 2011, he went on loan to a number of clubs, including [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] where he was named player of the year. Without making an appearance for Chelsea, he signed permanently to Championship club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2011 where he made over 100 appearances for them and helped them promoted to the Premier League by featuring in all their matches. Cork spent two and a half years with Premier League club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] from January 2015 to July 2017 before his permanent move to Burnley where he featured in every match en route of the club qualifying to the [[UEFA Europa League]].
Cork has featured for [[England national football team|England]] from U16 in 2005 to U21 between 2008 and 2011, the Great Britain Olympic team and once for the senior national team.
==Early life== Cork was born in [[Carshalton]], London.<ref>{{Hugman|22656|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> He is the son of former footballer and manager [[Alan Cork]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/365527/Southampton-star-Jack-Cork-wants-Saints-to-win-the-FA-Cup |title=Southampton star Jack Cork wants Saints to win the FA Cup |first=Alex |last=Crook |newspaper=Daily Star |location=London |date=15 February 2014 |accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref>
==Career== ===Chelsea=== Cork joined the [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] youth system up age of nine, and captained both the club's youth and reserve teams.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/TeamPlyrsBios/PlayersC/BioCorkJFP.html |title=England Football Online |date=14 May 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> During the [[2006–07 A.F.C. Bournemouth season|2006–07 season]], Cork twice went on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] to [[EFL League One|League One]] club [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|AFC Bournemouth]].<ref name=sb0607/> Cork was selected to go on Chelsea's pre-season tour of the United States in summer 2007. He made his first appearance for the first team against [[Club América]] on 14 July. He played out-of-position at left back for most of the tour.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1073236 |title=Minute Detail: Chelsea 2 Club America 1 |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140607021059/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/1073236 |archivedate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
Cork spent the [[2007–08 Scunthorpe United F.C. season|2007–08 season]] on loan at newly promoted [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]]. His first league goals came for Scunthorpe, both against [[Coventry City F.C.|Coventry City]]; in a 1–1 away draw on 27 November 2007<ref name=sb0708/> and in a 2–1 home victory on 1 March 2008.<ref>{{cite web |title=Scunthorpe 2–1 Coventry |publisher=BBC Sport |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7260445.stm |date=1 March 2008 |accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref> After 35 appearances,<ref name=sb0708/> despite Scunthorpe's relegation from the Championship,<ref>{{cite web |title=Championship: 2007/08: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=143 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> he was voted the club's Player of the Year.<ref name=ScunthorpePOTY>{{cite web |title=Vote for your Player of the Season 2016/17 |url=https://www.scunthorpe-united.co.uk/news/2017/march/vote-for-your-player-of-the-season-201617/ |publisher=Scunthorpe United F.C. |date=29 March 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
On 21 August 2008, Cork joined Championship club [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] on loan until 1 January 2009.<ref>{{cite news |title=Saints bag Chelsea's Cork on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/s/southampton/7574599.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=21 August 2008 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> In January 2009, Cork joined Championship club [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on loan until the end of the [[2008–09 Watford F.C. season|2008–09 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.watfordobserver.co.uk/sport/4015385.Hornets_snap_up_England_Under-21_international_Cork/ |title=Watford sign Chelsea's Jack Cork on loan until end of season |accessdate=13 July 2018 |date=2 January 2009 |first=Frank |last=Smith}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Watford on 24 January 2009 in a 4–3 victory over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] in the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/fa_cup/7842804.stm |title=Watford 4–3 Crystal Palace |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 January 2009 |accessdate=1 September 2009}}</ref> Cork signed a new three-year contract with Chelsea on 21 August 2009 and immediately joined Championship club Coventry City on loan until the end of December 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/chelsea-kid-jack-cork-handed-3372410 |title=Chelsea kid Jack Cork handed new three-year deal |publisher=Mirror |date=6 September 2009 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/coventry_city/8218228.stm |title=Cork may extend stay at Coventry |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 August 2009 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
On 1 February 2010, Cork joined Premier League club [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on loan until the end of the [[2009–10 Burnley F.C. season|2009–10 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Burnley boss delighted with signing of Chelsea youngster |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/b/burnley/8491608.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 February 2010 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> He made his first appearance for Burnley in a 3–0 defeat away to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on his Premier League debut.<ref name=sb0910/> He then played in a 5–2 defeat against Aston Villa on 21 February 2010 and assisted Burnley's second goal.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bevan |first=Chris |title=Aston Villa 5–2 Burnley |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8518684.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=20 June 2011 |date=21 February 2010}}</ref> Cork scored his first goal for Burnley on 9 May 2010 in a 4–2 home win over [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], with a diving header to score Burnley's second to turn over a two-goal lead.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8656546.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |title=Burnley 4–2 Tottenham |accessdate=20 June 2011 |date=9 May 2010}}</ref> His father revealed the day before in a local newspaper, the ''[[Lancashire Telegraph]]'', that Cork was looking to leave Chelsea in the summer and was willing to drop down into the Championship in order to do so.<ref>{{cite news |last=Flanagan |first=Chris |title=Burnley midfielder Cork is ready to leave Chelsea, says father |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/8154302.Burnley_midfielder_Cork_is_ready_to_leave_Chelsea__says_father/?ref=rss |newspaper=Lancashire Telegraph |location=Blackburn |date=8 May 2010 |accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref>
On 8 August 2010, Chelsea said that they would allow Cork to leave the club and were looking for offers of around £2 million.<ref>{{cite web |last=Scholes |first=Tony |title=Cork can go say Chelsea |url=http://www.clarets-mad.co.uk/news/tmnw/cork_can_go_say_chelsea_544341/index.shtml |work=Clarets Mad |publisher=Digital Sports Group |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=20 June 2011}}</ref> On 12 August, Cork re-joined Burnley on loan for the [[2010–11 Burnley F.C. season|2010–11 season]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Loan star Jack's the Lad – Again! |url=http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0,,10413~2119751,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120927082801/http://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/page/LatestHeadlines/0%2C%2C10413~2119751%2C00.html |archivedate=27 September 2012 |publisher=Burnley F.C. |date=12 August 2010 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Cork scored a last minute winner at home to [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 27 November, taking Burnley into the play-off positions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/9220843.stm |title=Burnley 2–1 Derby |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 November 2010 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
===Southampton=== [[File:Jack Cork v Villa.jpg|thumb|upright|Cork playing for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 2013]]
On 7 July 2011, Cork signed for newly promoted Championship club Southampton, after they agreed an undisclosed fee with Chelsea.<ref>{{cite web |title=Saints sign Jack Cork |url=http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~2388516,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110907120400/http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10280~2388516%2C00.html |archivedate=7 September 2011 |publisher=Southampton F.C. |date=7 July 2011 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> Cork ended the [[2011–12 Southampton F.C. season|2011–12 season]] as the only Southampton player who appeared in every league match,<ref name=sb1112/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/teams/team.sd?team_id=2471&teamTabs=stats |title=Southampton FC Player Appearances |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 September 2018}}</ref> as the club earned promotion to the [[Premier League]] as runners-up in the Championship.<ref name=1112table>{{cite web |title=Championship: 2011/12: Latest table |url=http://www.soccerbase.com/tournaments/tournament.sd?tourn_id=940 |work=Soccerbase |publisher=Centurycomm |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
Cork missed Southampton's opening fixtures of the [[2012–13 Premier League]], due to an ankle injury, sustained against [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in a friendly and a League Cup victory over [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/19181547 |title=Southampton midfielder Jack Cork out for up to six weeks |publisher=BBC Sport |date=27 September 2012 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref> On 26 August 2014, he scored his first goal for Southampton in a 2–0 away victory over [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] in the second round of the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Millwall 0–2 Southampton |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28847807 |accessdate=26 August 2014 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 August 2014}}</ref>
He scored his first league goal for the club in a 4–0 home win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 13 September 2014<ref>{{cite news |last1=Chowdhury |first1=Saj |title=Southampton 4–0 Newcastle |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29090536 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=19 October 2014 |date=13 September 2014}}</ref> and his second and final league goal for the club came in an 8–0 home win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 18 October.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Reddy |first1=Luke |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29580147 |title=Southampton 8–0 Sunderland |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 October 2014 |accessdate=18 October 2014}}</ref>
===Swansea City=== Cork signed for Southampton's Premier League rivals [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on 30 January 2015 on a three-and-a-half-year contract,<ref>{{cite news |title=Jack Cork: Swansea City finalise signing of Southampton midfielder |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31040534 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 January 2015 |date=30 January 2015}}</ref> for a fee "believed to be in the region of £3 million".<ref>{{cite news |title=Swansea complete £3m signing of Jack Cork from Southampton |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/jan/30/swansea-jack-cork-transfer-southampton |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=31 January 2015 |date=30 January 2015}}</ref> On 25 April 2015, he scored his first goal for Swansea in a 3–2 away win over Newcastle United.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/watch/video/sports/football/9822603/cork-nets-first-swansea-goal |title=Cork nets first Swansea goal |date=26 April 2015 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref>
Over a year after his first goal for the club, on 1 May 2016, he scored his second, with a 20-yard curling shot in a 3–1 home victory over [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/swansea-vs-liverpool/341544 |title=Swansea City 3–1 Liverpool |date=1 May 2016 |publisher=Sky Sports}}</ref> This victory helped secure Swansea's Premier League status for the [[2016–17 Swansea City A.F.C. season|2016–17 season]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36122791 |title=Swansea City 3–1 Liverpool |date=1 May 2017 |first=Dafydd |last=Pritchard |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref>
===Burnley=== Cork signed for Premier League club Burnley on 11 July 2017 on a four-year contract, for fee reported to be in the region of £8 million, rising to £10 million with add-ons.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cork: It's Great To Be Back! |url=https://www.burnleyfootballclub.com/news/2017/july/cork-its-great-to-be-back/ |publisher=Burnley F.C. |accessdate=11 July 2017 |date=11 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Pritchard |first1=Dafydd |title=Jack Cork: Burnley sign midfielder from Swansea City for about £10m |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40557497 |accessdate=11 July 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 July 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal on his return to Burnley in an [[EFL Cup]] tie against [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on 23 August 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40944670 |title=Blackburn Rovers 0–2 Burnley |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2017 |accessdate=29 August 2017}}</ref> His first Premier League goal for Burnley came against his former club Swansea City in a 2–0 win on 18 November. That goal ended a run of 43 appearances without a goal for the player.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Matthew |first1=Henry |title=Burnley 2–0 Swansea City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41951922 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 April 2018 |date=18 November 2017}}</ref>
On 16 August 2018, he scored the winning goal in Burnley's 1–0 victory over [[İstanbul Başakşehir F.K.|Istanbul Basaksehir]] in the Europa League qualifiers.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Emons |first1=Michael |title=Burnley 1–0 Istanbul Basaksehir |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45168370 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=17 August 2018 |date=16 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== ===England=== Cork has represented England at many youth levels, making his [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] debut against the [[Czech Republic national under-19 football team|Czech Republic]] in May 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/U19s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/05/U19sEliteRound_CzechReport.htm |archive-url=https://archive.is/20071029052657/http://www.thefa.com/England/U19s/NewsAndFeatures/Postings/2007/05/U19sEliteRound_CzechReport.htm |deadurl=yes |archivedate=29 October 2007 |title=Lions grab consolation |publisher=The Football Association}}</ref> He captained the England U19 squad to make the [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]], and was part of the [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] squad at the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lancashiretelegraph.co.uk/sport/5022592.Burnley_on-loan_star_Cork_earns_England_U21_selection/ |title=Burnley on-loan star Cork earns England U21 selection |publisher=Lancashire Telegraph |date=23 February 2018 |accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
On 7 November 2017, Cork was called into the [[England national football team|England]] squad for friendly matches against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Jack Cork: Burnley midfielder called up to England squad after trio withdraw |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41899819 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=7 November 2017 |date=7 November 2017}}</ref> He made his debut on 10 November 2017 as an 86th-minute substitute in a 0–0 draw against Germany at [[Wembley Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 0–0 Germany |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41854505 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 November 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> ===Great Britain Olympic team=== On 2 July 2012, Cork was named in [[Stuart Pearce]]'s 18-man [[Great Britain Olympic football team|Great Britain]] squad for the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2012 Summer Olympics]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Pearce names squad |url=http://www1.skysports.com/olympics/story/15234/7859286 |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721195910/http://www1.skysports.com/olympics/story/15234/7859286 |archivedate=21 July 2010}}</ref> He made his debut on 20 July in a 2–0 loss to [[Brazil national under-23 football team|Brazil]] in a pre-tournament friendly, coming on at half-time to replace [[Daniel Sturridge]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Duncan |last=White |title=London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain 0 Brazil 2 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/football/9416665/London-2012-Olympics-Great-Britain-0-Brazil-2.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=20 July 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref> He played as a substitute in each of Great Britain's three group matches, and was an unused substitute as the team were knocked out by [[South Korea national under-23 football team|South Korea]] in the quarter-final.<ref>{{cite news |first=Henry |last=Winter |title=London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain 1 Senegal 1 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/football/9430902/London-2012-Olympics-Great-Britain-1-Senegal-1.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=26 July 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2017}}<br />{{cite news |first=Henry |last=Winter |title=London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain overcome UAE to set up Uruguay decider |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/football/9437204/London-2012-Olympics-Great-Britain-overcome-UAE-to-set-up-Uruguay-decider.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=30 July 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2017}}<br />{{cite news |first=Henry |last=Winter |title=London 2012 Olympics: Great Britain 1 Uruguay 0 – Match report |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/football/9445523/London-2012-Olympics-Great-Britain-1-Uruguay-0-match-report.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=2 August 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2017}}<br />{{cite news |first=Henry |last=Winter |title=London 2012 Olympics; Team GB 1 South Korea 1 aet (4–5 pens): Match report |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/football/9452962/London-2012-Olympics-Team-GB-1-South-Korea-1-aet-4-5-pens-match-report.html |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=4 August 2012 |accessdate=14 November 2017}}</ref>

|[[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] (loan) |[[2007–08 Scunthorpe United F.C. season|2007–08]]<ref name=sb0708>{{soccerbase season|45288|2007|accessdate=11 November 2017}}</ref> |[[EFL Championship|Championship]] |34||2||1||0||colspan=2|—||colspan=2|—||35||2 |- |[[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] (loan) |[[2008–09 Southampton F.C. season|2008–09]]<ref name=sb0809/> |Championship |23||0||colspan=2|—||2||0||colspan=2|—||25||0 |- |[[Watford F.C.|Watford]] (loan) |[[2008–09 Watford F.C. season|2008–09]]<ref name=sb0809>{{soccerbase season|45288|2008|accessdate=11 November
